page.title: 03Tetsworth Parish Church
page.content: There is evidence of a church building in Tetsworth since medieval times, but the present building dates from 1844. The church, dedicated to St.Giles, stands on a hill overlooking the parish. It was probably paid for by a vicar of the parish who is remembered by a plaque inside the church. There are three parts to the church. The tower, on the south side, has six bells. The nave is the largest part and simply furnished. A record in the vestry shows the number of seats in the church. The appropriated seats still have doors on them. The other pews (free and children's) do not have doors and are not so roomy. The Chancel is small and contains choir stalls and the altar. The east window is a stained glass window and describes when Jesus went to heaven for ever. In the nave is a two manual organ.
